Colin,

Just curious as I've been thinking about this a bit lately (I'm new=
 to NEAT
stuff), as it seems that the micro mutations you talk about, if
I'=
m interpreting papers right, is one of the reasons standard NEAT doesn't
ha=
ndle fractured domain problems well. As you say, it can't "get there from
h=
ere". It can't build enough structure and optimize it's performance to find=

a better solution before that species dies out.

Is this the problem you'r=
e looking to address here? Or just a method of
escaping a local maxima in f=
itness by allowing more radical
adjustments/growth to network topologies in=
 general?

One thing I was wondering about, and I haven't poked around to s=
ee if anyone
has done some research into, is fiddling with the species die-=
off parameter.
I was thinking it might be worth trying (if someone hasn't d=
one it yet), is
to remove the species die off if-hasn't-improved-in X gener=
ations bit if no
species fitness has improved in some specified amount of g=
enerations.

I think if you've sat with the same "champion" for a large num=
ber of
generations, it could be worthwhile to do something radical, like gr=
eatly
increase mutations, stop killing off sub-performing species, greatly
=
increase the topology, or even (if you have a cluster, or a lot of time),
s=
top restricting the population size (that could get ugly quick). Let the
po=
pulation grow on it's own for X generations, to help diversify things a
bit=
. After X generations of population explosion, go back to a set
population =
size by killing off the under performing species.

If figure that if you're=
 seemingly stuck in what appears to be a local
maxima in the solution space=
, why not slow things down a bit with a huge
population, larger mutations, =
to diversify the search a bit?

I'm sure someone has toyed with this at som=
e point. I can always use another
couple hundred of pages of papers/dissert=
ations to add to my "to-be-read"
pile going into my thesis :)

Sorry if I'm=
 rambling, pre-coffee here.


-Drew

On Thu, Mar 24, 2011 at 11:43 PM, Coli=
n Green <colin.green1@...>wrote:

>
>
> This is an idea that follows =
from the discussion on networks with
> arbitrary complexity possibly being =
useful as starting points for
> biological brains.
>
> Very simply I'm cons=
idering experimenting with random initial
> populations of varying sizes & =
complexities (and perhaps schemes for
> generating random connections/nodes=
) and then running NEAT in pruning
> mode first before complexifying. The p=
runing potentially gets you back
> to a population of low complexity networ=
ks that have more diversity
> than we normally start with. The motivation i=
s that this might help in
> the "you can't get there from here" problem of =
being stuck in some
> sub-space of the fitness landscape. Starting with no =
nodes or even no
> connections puts the whole population in one part of the=
 sub-space
> from which it might struggle to escape - this is especially tr=
ue if
> you factor neywork size into the fitness function which is an idea
=
> I've bounced around before.
>
> Further to this I'm also thinking about n=
etwork mutations that do more
> than the current 'micro' mutations we all t=
end to use (add/delete
> connection or weight change). We sort of do someth=
ing like this
> already in that a weight change mutation can be for a singl=
e
> connection or applied to all or some proportion of connections. In
> ad=
dition I propose that connection addition/deletion mutations that
> perform=
 multiple mutations as one operation might have beneficial
> effects over a=
nd above the normal approach of aggregating positive
> mutations over time =
and through crossover. Again the motivation is in
> helping NEAT to make sl=
ightly bolder jumps into new regions of the
> fitness space (but not too bo=
ld).
>
> One can also invisage having a very large number of new connection=
s as
> part of a single mutation, but that have very low connection weights=

> such that they are almost functionally redundant (but not entirely).
> T=
he beneficial connections may 'grow' in strength and the useless ones
> wou=
ld get eliminated during pruning.
>
> Colin
>  
>

--00248c6a5572e4bb8b049f4e0d2c

ering about, and I haven't poked around to see if anyone has done some =

ng it might be worth trying (if someone hasn't done it yet), is to remo=
ve the species die off if-hasn't-improved-in X generations bit if no sp=

mething radical, like greatly increase mutations, stop killing off sub-perf=
orming species, greatly increase the topology, or even (if you have a clust=

 ugly quick). Let the population grow on it's own for X generations, to=
 help diversify things a bit. After X generations of population explosion, =
go back to a set population size by killing off the under performing specie=
s.=A0</div>

ck in what appears to be a local maxima in the solution space, why not slow=

/a>></span> wrote:<br>

<blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margi=
n:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padding-left:1ex;">













<d=
iv style=3D"background-color:#fff">
<span>=A0</span>


<div>
  <div>


    =
<div>
      
      
      <p>This is an idea that follows from the discussi=
on on networks with<br>
arbitrary complexity possibly being useful as start=
ing points for<br>
biological brains.<br>
<br>
Very simply I'm consider=
ing experimenting with random initial<br>
populations of varying sizes &amp=
; complexities (and perhaps schemes for<br>
generating random connections/n=
odes) and then running NEAT in pruning<br>
mode first before complexifying.=
 The pruning potentially gets you back<br>
to a population of low complexit=
y networks that have more diversity<br>
than we normally start with. The mo=
tivation is that this might help in<br>
the "you can't get there f=
rom here" problem of being stuck in some<br>
sub-space of the fitness =
landscape. Starting with no nodes or even no<br>
connections puts the whole=
 population in one part of the sub-space<br>
from which it might struggle t=
o escape - this is especially true if<br>
you factor neywork size into the =
fitness function which is an idea<br>
I've bounced around before.<br>
<=
br>
Further to this I'm also thinking about network mutations that do m=
ore<br>
than the current 'micro' mutations we all tend to use (add/=
delete<br>
connection or weight change). We sort of do something like this<=
br>
already in that a weight change mutation can be for a single<br>
connec=
tion or applied to all or some proportion of connections. In<br>
addition I=
 propose that connection addition/deletion mutations that<br>
perform multi=
ple mutations as one operation might have beneficial<br>
effects over and a=
bove the normal approach of aggregating positive<br>
mutations over time an=
d through crossover. Again the motivation is in<br>
helping NEAT to make sl=
ightly bolder jumps into new regions of the<br>
fitness space (but not too =
bold).<br>
<br>
One can also invisage having a very large number of new con=
nections as<br>
part of a single mutation, but that have very low connectio=
n weights<br>
such that they are almost functionally redundant (but not ent=
irely).<br>
The beneficial connections may 'grow' in strength and t=
he useless ones<br>
would get eliminated during pruning.<br>
<br>
Colin<br>=

</p>
